{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-34148].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
At present, an unlimited number of users can concurrently edit a page. As a result, the last user that saves could potentially overwrite content to the page.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide users the ability to limit the number of users who can concurrently edit, or disable the feature entirely and allow only one user at a time to edit. Additionally, can add a temporary lock to a page that might have a lot of edits in a certain amount of time.
 
h3. Workaround 
Restrict Editing to certain users in [Page Restrictions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Page+Restrictions]
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to disable or limit number of concurrent users editing a page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-34132].
  {panel}

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new space with Default theme and Global colour scheme.

2. Change theme, eg. to Atlassian’s Documentation theme or in our case, to our own custom theme. Global Colour Scheme has been replaced by either Theme Colour Scheme (Documentation theme) or Custom Colour Scheme (own custom theme).

3. Switch back to Default theme. The colour scheme won’t revert back to Global Colour scheme but stays the same as after previous step.

I think it’s not a bug in a theme, since it doesn’t matter if the other theme is Atlassian’s Documentation Theme or our own custom theme. 

This is not a major issue, but could be very confusing if individual space admins will just want to try a different theme for a moment but want to change back to original. Restoring the original situation need some extra steps to complete.
fields.summary: Space’s colour scheme won’t revert back to Global colour scheme if the theme is changed from Default to some other and back.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-34126].
  {panel}

We're finding the decision register really useful but there is one feature that I think would really increase productivity - the ability for notifications to be sent out for pending decisions on a configurable basis.

We're starting to use the decision register for a lot of the technical decisions we make as architects within our company. A lot of these decisions can take time to make. To encourage people to keep on top of them I send out an E-mail on a regular basis, but it would be ideal if this was automated.

I am guessing the nature of a decision register page means it is not particularly structured, i.e. it is just a regular page with some pre-selected markup? A temporary workaround could be to use the REST API I guess to pull this info out, I just don't know if there would be anything that would distinguish a decision register page from any other page.

Thanks
Michael
fields.summary: Automated follow up notifications for pending decisions in the decision register

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-34089].
  {panel}

*Problem:*
Confluence sends the daily _Recommended Updates_ e-mail even when there's no activity.

*Details:*
The [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Subscribing+to+Email+Notifications+of+Updates+to+Confluence+Content] says: _If there is no activity to report, Confluence will not send the email message._
However, even if there's no activity on the instance, Confluence keeps sending the daily e-mail with the same content as the last e-mail sent.

*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Configure your Confluence to be able to send e-mails.
# Set the default schedule for sending the recommended updates e-mail to *Daily*, under under *Confluence Admin > Recommended Updates Email > Default Schedule*.
# Be sure that your user has a valid e-mail configured under its account details.
# Create a page in Confluence with *another user* and save it.
# Like and comment on the page with the user who created the page.
# The e-mail is sent at 1P.M everyday, so set the date time on your instance's server to 1P.M of the next day.
# Wait for the e-mail on your inbox.
# Set the server date time to 1P.M of the next day again.
# The same e-mail as the last one will be sent.
fields.summary: Daily email being sent even when there's nothing new

After changing the Title column heading to a different name in 'Page properties report' Macro. 
User cannot sort using the different name that he/she have changed. User has to enter "title" to sort. This will confused the user as they do not know they have to use "title" to sort even after they have changed the title name.

Below are the steps to reproduce this:
1. Login to Confluence
2. Go to a Space page
3. Create a new page within the Space
4. In the editor, choose Insert > Other Macros > Page Properties
5. In the macro body create a two column table and remove the header row.
6. In the left column list your 'keys' - these will be the column headings in your report table.
7. In the right column list the value for each key - these will populate the rows in your report table.
8. Add a label to your page - you will need to specify this label in the page properties report macro.
9.Save your page. 

Do this process for a few subsequent new pages.

After that, go to a existing page and choose Insert > Other Macros > Page Properties Report

Input the string "Name" into "Title column heading".

Input "Name" in "Sort by""

Current result : It does not sort after Title have been changed to Name. 
Expected result : It should sort after Title have been changed to Name.
fields.summary: "Page properties report" macro can only be sort using "title"

h5.Steps to Reproduce:

# Create an expand block
# Inside the expansion block, create a code block, and set {{collapsible=true}}
# Save the page
# Click the expansion link to show the codeblock in it's collapsed state
# Click the codeblock's expansion link

The storage format for the example is as follows:

{code}
<ac:structured-macro ac:name="expand">
  <ac:rich-text-body>
    <ac:structured-macro ac:name="code">
      <ac:parameter ac:name="linenumbers">true</ac:parameter>
      <ac:parameter ac:name="collapse">true</ac:parameter>
      <ac:plain-text-body>
        <![CDATA[#style { font-weight: bold; }]]>
      </ac:plain-text-body>
    </ac:structured-macro>
  </ac:rich-text-body>
</ac:structured-macro>
{code}

h5.Expected Results
The code block should expand and be visible.

h5.Actual Result
The code block expands, and disappears as the outer expand is (incorrectly) collapsed.

h5.Workaround
Expand the outer expand macro again, to reveal the expanded codeblock.

h5.Notes
The reverse is well - collapse the code block, and the outer expand will collapse as well.
fields.summary: Collapsible code macro inside expand block doesn't work as expected

The column header is displayed using capitalisation. Inspecting the header column reveals the following inline style applied to all of the header columns in the table:

{code}
style="text-align: left; text-transform: capitalize;"
{code}

Additionally, the text inside the header column is lower case.

Another step along the path of confluence towards becoming the documentation development environment of choice should be the tightening of control over the application of styles. The present editor provides 9 controlled styles and there is a tool bar that allows users to control the appearance of text in any manner.

I suggest that site and space configuration options include the ability to:

- declare and define the contents of the paragraph styles dropdown
- declare and define the contents of a new font styles dropdown
- declare and define the contents of a table styles dropdown
- force the remove of the ad hoc settings dropdown

When templates and blueprints are employed, the above features would allow site and space managers to fully control the styling of documentation produced using confluence.

The above styles would apply equally to PDF and HTML exports.

At the moment I can restrict view and edit of pages based on users and groups. I would prefere a role based model.

This model would alow to define roles on the space similar to project roles in JIRA. You could then add user and groups to the roles (again just like in JIRA).
Giving the roles meaningfull names would allow for more crear restrictions like:
* Restrict view to "technical writer", "developer" and "customer"
* Restrict edit to "technical writer"

It would make setting restrictions more easy for normal user as they could use are meaning full role name to restrict there pages instead of figuring out witch group would be the right choice. (You could also use good names for groups to support this.)

This would also make changes in the restrictions more easy, as you could change youst witch user and groups have witch role instead of changeing alle ristrictions in the space.
fields.summary: Role Based Restrictions
